We are two students in computer science and are currently working on a new open source project involving OmniSharp.

There is a typescript based plugin for Visual Studio Code providing support for the language Dafny (https://github.com/DafnyVSCode/Dafny-VSCode). 
The plugin uses the LSP to communicate with a language server, which then communicates with the Dafny server. The implementation uses 2 APIs. Our goal is to reimplement the language server and unite it with the Dafny server. Our implementation will be in C# using OmniSharp.

Unfortunately, we can’t find any documentation and there are only few tutorials. Is there any starting guide or tutorial? We already inspected the example server but it only supports a few features. We also worked through the tutorial from Martin Björkström [https://martinbjorkstrom.com/posts/2018-11-29-creating-a-language-server]. Is there a more extensive example project or any way to discover the full OmnsiSharp API with examples? A little more help getting into OmniSharp would be really great! :-)

There are many small samples for updating a buffered version of the client’s file. However, implementing a different service feature is kinda difficult without documentation. We kinda tried to implement ‚good sounding‘ interfaces and ‚hoped it would be the right one‘. 

Thank you very much for any support :-)

Cheers 
Tom and Marcel

answers.body_markdown:
> My calculation of the entry point should also be correct, I guess. And the rip is pointing to the _start function,

There is *no way* that `_start` is located at `0x1080` (at least not on Linux).

If `readelf` tells you that that's the address of `_start`, then you have a position-independent executable.

PIE executables didn't exist until a few years ago, so the book probably doesn't mention you need a non-PIE one (since at the time of writing non-PIE binaries were all that you could build/run).

To build a non-PIE binary, use `g++ -fno-pie -no-pie hello.cc`. After doing that, the rest of code injection should work like it does in the book.

In a later chapter, we have written an injector for ELF type files.
The injector places a code section at location 0x80000 [+offset %16], overwriting the .note.ABI-tag section (which contains only information unrelated to execution, so it's safe to overwrite it).

The program I am modding is a simple hello_username program, like this:

    #include <iostream>

    using namespace std;

    main()
    {
	    cout << "hello Lucky" << endl;
	    return 0;
    }

        BITS 64

    section .text
    global main

    main:

	    push	rax
	    push 	rcx
	    push	rdx
	    push 	rsi
	    push	rdi
	    push	r11


        mov rax, 	0x1					;syscall to print (sys_write)
        mov rdi,	0x1					;stdout

answers.title: Python List Comprehension is not returning a new List

answers.body_markdown:
`x * 2` is an expression which evaluates to a result and its result will be stored in the list `M`. 

`x.append(100)` on the other hand applies function `append()` on the object `x`, which is an element of list `L` and returns `None`.

It is the same, why you do `y = x * 2`, but not `y = x.append(100)`.
answers.title: Python List Comprehension is not returning a new List

answers.body_markdown:
You are appending to `x`, is an element in `L`, that is why `L` changes. If you want a new list do not mutate a older, create a new one.

You don't specify a result you expect, but I believe this what your looking for:
```python
>>> L = [[1], [2], [3]]
>>> M = [[*x, 100] for x in L]
>>> L
[[1], [2], [3]]
>>> M
[[1, 100], [2, 100], [3, 100]]
```
answers.title: Python List Comprehension is not returning a new List

items.body_markdown:
I am surprised by the behavior of `List Comprehension` on a `list` of `lists`. I would expect `List comprehension` to return a new list to me ALWAYS. For example:

```python
>>> L = [1,2,3,4,5,6]
>>> M = [ x * 2 for x in L]
>>> L
>>> [1,2,3,4,5,6]
>>> M
>>> [2,4,6,8,10,12]
``` 
So `L` is not changed.

However,

```python

>>> L = [[1], [2], [3]]
>>> M = [x.append(100) for x in L]
>>> M
>>> [None, None, None]
>>> L
>>> [[1,100], [2,100], [3,100]]
```
Now L is changed and `list comprehension` does not return a new List.

I am expecting a new List by the list comprehension. Any explanation would help me to understand this behavior of `list comprehension`
items.title: Python List Comprehension is not returning a new List

    case 
        when e.Application is null or e.Application = ''
    then 
        CAST(e.AllXml as Xml).value('(/error/@application)[1]','varchar(max)') 
    else
        e.Application
    end as Application,
    e.Type
    from dbo.temp_error e with (nolock)
    ) as e
    group by 
    e.Host, 
    e.Application

answers.body_markdown:
First of all, `seq(from=1, to=4, length=T)` returns `1`, so your code only creates 1 group. I thus modified your code as follows.

    data=mtcars
    data$group = rep(1:4, each = 8)

We can use the functions to apply `glm` to each combination as follows.

    library(tidyverse)
    
    data2 <- data %>%
      gather(Y, Value, vs, am) %>%
      group_split(Y, group) %>%
      set_names(nm = map_chr(., ~str_c(unique(.x$Y), unique(.x$group), sep = "-"))) %>%
      map(~glm(Value ~ mpg + cyl + disp + hp, data = .x, family = "binomial"))

We can access the result by names
    
    data2[["am-1"]]
    # Call:  glm(formula = Value ~ mpg + cyl + disp + hp, family = "binomial", 
    #            data = .x)
    # 
    # Coefficients:
    # (Intercept)          mpg          cyl         disp           hp  
    #     4.9180      -0.5335      17.2521      -0.7975       0.5192  
    # 
    # Degrees of Freedom: 7 Total (i.e. Null);  3 Residual
    # Null Deviance:	    10.59 
    # Residual Deviance: 2.266e-10 	AIC: 10

    data3 <- data %>%
      gather(Y, Value, vs, am) %>%
      group_by(Y, group) %>%
      nest() %>%
      mutate(Model = map(data, ~glm(Value ~ mpg + cyl + disp + hp, data = .x, family = "binomial")))
    data3
    # # A tibble: 8 x 4
    # # Groups:   group, Y [8]
    #   group Y                data Model 
    #   <int> <chr> <list<df[,10]>> <list>
    # 1     1 vs           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 2     2 vs           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 3     3 vs           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 4     4 vs           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 5     1 am           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 6     2 am           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 7     3 am           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    # 8     4 am           [8 x 10] <glm> 
    
    data3 %>%
      filter(group == 1, Y == "am") %>%
      pull(Model)
    # [[1]]
    # 
    # Call:  glm(formula = Value ~ mpg + cyl + disp + hp, family = "binomial", 
    #            data = .x)
    # 
    # Coefficients:
    # (Intercept)          mpg          cyl         disp           hp  
    #      4.9180      -0.5335      17.2521      -0.7975       0.5192  
    # 
    # Degrees of Freedom: 7 Total (i.e. Null);  3 Residual
    # Null Deviance:	    10.59 
    # Residual Deviance: 2.266e-10 	AIC: 10

You can extract the information with `mutate` and `map`, like below.


    data4 <- data3 %>% mutate(Coef = map(Model, coef))

    data4 %>%
      filter(group == 1, Y == "am") %>%
      pull(Coef)
    # [[1]]
    # (Intercept)         mpg         cyl        disp          hp 
    #   4.9179574  -0.5334823  17.2520829  -0.7974839   0.5191961 

Or use the functions from the `broom` package.

    library(broom)

    data5 <- data3 %>%
      mutate(Info = map(Model, tidy)) %>%
      select(-Model, -data) %>%
      unnest(cols = "Info")
    data5
    # # A tibble: 40 x 7
    # # Groups:   group, Y [8]
    #   group Y     term        estimate std.error  statistic p.value
    #    <int> <chr> <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>   <dbl>
    #  1     1 vs    (Intercept)  397.     4682905.  0.0000849   1.000
    #  2     1 vs    mpg           -8.95    176775. -0.0000507   1.000
    #  3     1 vs    cyl          -41.9     141996. -0.000295    1.000
    #  4     1 vs    disp           0.525     1510.  0.000348    1.000
    #  5     1 vs    hp            -0.610     8647. -0.0000705   1.000
    #  6     2 vs    (Intercept)  126.     2034044.  0.0000619   1.000
    #  7     2 vs    mpg           -0.965    69501. -0.0000139   1.000
    #  8     2 vs    cyl           25.6     398854.  0.0000642   1.000
    #  9     2 vs    disp           0.266     3917.  0.0000680   1.000
    # 10     2 vs    hp            -2.29     19162. -0.000120    1.000
    # # ... with 30 more rows

```javascript
import { obj } from '../../static_data/nationality_list';
```

```javascript
export default {
```

answers.body_markdown:
## How to do it quicker:
You can just use a set, to achieve the same thing:
```
destinations = ['test.aws.amazon.com', 'aws.amazon.com', 'amazon.com', '.example.com', 'url.example.com', 'net.example.com']

primary_domains = set([])

for destination in destinations:
    primary_domain = '.'.join(destination.split(".")[-2:])
    primary_domains.add(primary_domain)

print(primary_domains)
```
Result:
```
{'amazon.com', 'example.com'}
```

## How it works:

`set` cannot have duplicate values. If you add the same thing multiple times, you'll still only have one of them

`destination.split(".")` splits on the dots. `[-2:]` grabs the last two items. `'.'.join()` joins it back with dots

## Why yours doesn't work:

1. Cleaned list is just `net.example.com` because when you `cleaned_list = destinations.pop()` it takes the last item from `destinations`, removes it, and assigns it to `cleaned_list`

2. Because the regex fill match everything that comes before it, and because regex is greedy, you'll get as `results`:
```
['test.aws.amazon.com']
['test.aws.amazon.com aws.amazon.com']
['test.aws.amazon.com aws.amazon.com amazon.com']
['test.aws.amazon.com aws.amazon.com amazon.com .example.com url.example.com net.example.com']
['test.aws.amazon.com aws.amazon.com amazon.com .example.com url.example.com']
['test.aws.amazon.com aws.amazon.com amazon.com .example.com url.example.com net.example.com']
```
3. Even if those 2 worked, you might remove items from your cleared list, that you've already removed, resulting in an error.

## How to do it, if you want to filter not just by primary domain

As you've said in a comment, if you sometimes have to deal with not just primary domains, here is a more generic solution, for finding strings, that are part substrings of other strings:
```
import itertools

destinations = ['test.aws.amazon.com', 'aws.amazon.com', 'amazon.com', '.example.com', 'url.example.com', 'net.example.com', 'dev.whatever.company.com.pl', 'company.com.pl']

substrings = {}

for v1, v2 in itertools.product(destinations, destinations):
    if v1 in v2 and v1 != v2:
        substrings[v1] = substrings.get(v1, []) + [v2]

substrings = {key: value for key, value in substrings.items() if not any(k in key and key != k for k in substrings.keys())}

print(substrings)
```
Result:
```
{'amazon.com': ['test.aws.amazon.com', 'aws.amazon.com'], '.example.com': ['url.example.com', 'net.example.com'], 'company.com.pl': ['dev.whatever.company.com.pl']}
```

answers.body_markdown:
# Solution for cleaning up the list of destinations #
Generate a rule for squid proxy.

Customer is sending a list of domains and IPs. This list has to be checked and filtered.

* Filter out all duplicate entries
* If domain has a `dot` in front, this means that all subdomains will be included `(.examle.com includes for example whatever.example.com)` so every other subdomain from that url has to be removed from destinations list.
* If a domain has NO `dot` in front the proxy clearing is dedicated for that url, so in case there is `mystuff.com and subdomain.mystuff.com` in the list, both should be remain in the same.


**Python code for that solution**
```
>>> destinations = ['test.aws.amazon.com', 'aws.amazon.com', '.amazon.com', 'example.com', 'url.example.com', 'times.org', 'net.example.com', 'www.north.com', 'north.com', '.mydest.co.at', 'mydest.co.at', '213.12.23.22/32', 'amazon.com', 'www.somother.net', '.amazon.at']
>>> destinations = set(destinations)
>>> for d1, d2 in itertools.product(destinations, destinations):
...     if d1 != d2 and d1[0] == '.':
...         if re.findall(d1[1:], d2):
...             destinations.remove(d2)
... 
>>> destinations
['.amazon.com', 'example.com', 'url.example.com', 'times.org', 'net.example.com', 'www.north.com', 'north.com', '.mydest.co.at', '213.12.23.22/32', 'www.somother.net']
 ```

**Thanks to "tituszban" for the help**

answers.title: Delete substring between delimiters in python
Delete substring between delimiters in python

answers.body_markdown:
With [`str.index`][1] feature:

    s = "This $\textbf{word}$ must be deleted"
    pos = s.index('$')
    res = s[:pos] + s[s.index('$', pos + 1) + 1:].strip()
    print(res)   # This must be deleted


----------
For *symmetric* delimiters:

    s = "This {word} must be deleted"
    res = s[:s.find('{')] + s[s.rfind('}') + 1:].strip()
    print(res)   # This must be deleted

  [1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str.index

I wrote a program in python which gets the average color of every frame, to create a poster like this:

[![][1]][1]


This is the function I use to create my own image with PIL:

~~~python
def create_poster_wave():
    # creates png with pixel height equal to the analysed frames, width is 2/3 of height (standard poster format)
    # draws a line each loop whose width depends on relative brightness of frame to create wave effect
    height = file_len()
    width = int(height / 1.5)
    mid = int(width / 2)
    min_line_width = int(width / 8)
    img = Image.new('RGB', (width, height), color='black')
    with open(MOVIE_TITLE) as file:
        color_list = [tuple(map(int, i.split(','))) for i in file]
    counter = 0
    draw = ImageDraw.Draw(img)
    brightness = get_color_brightness(color_list[0])
    last_len = int(min_line_width ** (1 + 0.1 * brightness)) # brightness = value between 0&1, by converting color to grayscale
    for color in color_list:
        brightness = get_color_brightness(color)
        actual_len = int(min_line_width * (1 + brightness))
        actual_len = int((actual_len + last_len) / 2)
        last_len = actual_len
        left = (mid - actual_len, counter)
        right = (mid + actual_len, counter)
        draw.line([left, right], fill=color)
        counter += 1
        print(counter)
    del draw
    img.save("PosterWave.png")
~~~

As you can see I draw a horizontal line for every frame color. The length of the line depends on the brightness of the color (which I assume the original creator did as well) (brightness is a value from 0-1, by converting to grayscale and then dividing by 255) and on the length of the last line, to smooth out large jumps. The result I get however is this:

[![][2]][2]

As you can see, the gaps between the lines are way too large and don't give the illusion of a wave form at all. Do you have any suggestions about the math that is needed to create a smoother alignment of the lines? Thanks a lot.

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/YCosr.png

```c++
this->nodeName[15] = nodeName;
```

That assigns a value to the *nonexistent* (!) 16th character of `this->nodeName`. And yes, I said *16th* character, not 15th, since indexing in C++ is 0-based (e.g., the first character is `nodeName[0]`, second is `nodeName[1]`, 15th is `nodeName[14]`).

The value assigned to `this->nodeName` is probably a pointer to the first character of `nodeName`, converted to a `char`, which is almost certainly not what you want. If you absolutely *must* use a character array for `nodeName`, then you can do this:

```c++
std::strncpy(this->nodeName, nodeName, 15);
this->nodeName[14] = '\0'; // Ensuring NUL-termination, even if something
                           // is wonky with nodeName
```

However, I would highly second uneven_mark's recommendation to make `nodeName` be of type `std::string`. rather than a fixed-length character array. Dealing with `strncpy` and its fellow fiends can be tricky.

The other problem in your code is here:

```c++
Serial.println(nodeName[15]);
```
Again, this prints the *nonexistent* (!) 16th character of `nodeName`. If you use a character array for `nodeName`, then you should just write

```c++
Serial.println(nodeName);
```

If you wisely have `nodeName` be a `std::string`, then [you may need to write][1]

```c++
Serial.println(nodeName.c_str());
```
instead.

  [1]: https://arduino.stackexchange.com/questions/56365/arduino-convert-stdstring-to-string

answers.title: How can a std::filesystem root path have itself as a parent?

answers.body_markdown:
Actually there is no output in the godbolt example, because the test is run on GCC on a posix environment, where `"C:\\"` is not a root directory, so it is seen as a strange directory/file name and its parent is empty, but with the [correct posix root path](https://godbolt.org/z/PhBew_) `"/"` it would have given the output, as the OP is observing.
So no, parent_path() of a root directory (`"/"` or `"C:\\"`) is not empty, so has_parent_path() is true on all implementations of std::filesystem I know of.

The actual standard says: _"Returns: `*this` if `has_relative_path()` is `false`, otherwise a path whose generic format pathname is the longest prefix of the generic format pathname of `*this` that produces one fewer element in its iteration."_ and `relative_path()` is everything after the `root_path()`, so there is no `relative_path()` in this case, so `parent_path()` returns `*this` and `has_parent_path()` returns true, as in the example of the OP.

My guess with the question of why the standard chose this behaviour is, that this is what `cd ..` does on every OS, if you are already at the root, you stay at the same root.

Indeed one possible way of detecting the end is: `(!p.has_parent_path() || !p.has_relative_path())` or maybe even `!p.has_relative_path()`, depending on if you want to end with an empty path if it was rootless.

answers.body_markdown:
The build process of a Homebrew package is defined in a file called formula, which is written in Ruby.

> A formula is a package definition written in Ruby. It can be created with `brew create <URL>` where <URL> is a zip or tarball, installed with `brew install <formula>`.

You can get the formula for `fftw` from [homebrew/core/Formula/fftw.rb](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/master/Formula/fftw.rb).

And the configuration options are defined in the `args` array.

```ruby
# https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/e7c8239a8a7c9b4501c4a18a4028cae82e254984/Formula/fftw.rb#L21-L30

  def install
    args = [
      "--enable-shared",
      "--disable-debug",
      "--prefix=#{prefix}",
      "--enable-threads",
      "--disable-dependency-tracking",
      "--enable-mpi",
      "--enable-openmp",
    ]
```

Download the `fftw.rb` formula file and change the configuration options. After that, install the modified formula by building it from source.

```shell
brew install --build-from-source local/path/to/modified-fftw.rb
```

### Extended Reading
To get how to write your own formula. Check

- [Formula Cookbook](https://docs.brew.sh/Formula-Cookbook)
- [How to Create and Maintain a Tap](https://docs.brew.sh/How-to-Create-and-Maintain-a-Tap)

### FAQ
Why `brew edit fftw` is not recommended?

Homebrew is made of two parts: the `brew` command and formula repos. `fftw.rb` is a formula defined in the built-in, **local** formula repo [homebrew-core](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core). When you use `brew edit fftw`, you are editing the file from the local repo directly. Unless you're going to contribute to this repo, don't edit files within the homebrew-core repo directly.

answers.body_markdown:
When using Hibernate as a JPA provider the `Stream<User> findAll()` will result in a lazy cursor (see [this question as well][1]). This means it will only fetch the amount of records that is specified by the JDBC fetch-size. It will not put all records from the database (if there are more then 1000) into memory, like what happens with a `List<User> findAll()`. 

So unless you are holding onto the `User` object in your code and collect them into a collection/array the memory should be released periodically. 

[1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44642556/advantages-of-stream-and-spring-data

answers.body_markdown:
It is not possible to use R8 to address this problem. Even when `org.apache.commons.codec.digest.DigestUtils` is renamed, it will still use `org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Hex` from the Android framework, which does not include the method `encodeHexString`. See https://stackoverflow.com/a/29833101/2418642 for the details.

You will need to use a tool like [Shadow](https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow) to repackage your own version of commons-codec.

answers.body_markdown:
You can't, per se. You are beholden to what the library uses. `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging` is a facade, so when you depend on that, the application can sub in an actual logging provider. However, when the library depends on the provider itself (i.e. Serilog), then there's no way to hook it into `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging` or another provider.

That said, the same Serilog config can be used for both, if you also use the Serilog provider for `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging`. They wouldn't be generating the logs in the same way, but they'd all end up in the same sink(s). Additionally, Serilog is somewhat of a facade itself, with its concept of sinks, so while you ultimately can't get rid of Serilog, you can configure different logging destinations via Serilog, instead of using different `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging` providers.
answers.title: How to log messages issued by serilog in a nuget package in my ASP.NET Core app using ILogger

```python
MES_LEN_SPACE = 20
```

```python
im = ImageGrab.grab()

send_data_by_protocol_in_chunks(msg, client_socket)
```

```python
def send_data_by_protocol_in_chunks(data, client_socket):
    num_of_chunks = len(data) // CHUNKS_LEN
    for i in range(num_of_chunks + 1):
        send_data_by_protocol(data[i * CHUNKS_LEN: (i + 1) * CHUNKS_LEN], client_socket)
    send_data_by_protocol(END_CODE, client_socket)
```

**This is the "send_data_by_protocol()" function:**
```python
def send_data_by_protocol(msg, client_socket):
    msg_length = len(str(msg))
    message_by_protocol = f"{msg_length:<{MES_LEN_SPACE}}{msg}".encode('utf-8')
```
